intro: Diapedium ciliare, commonly known as the silky mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees, primarily in tropical and subtropical regions. It has small, leathery leaves that are often covered with fine, silky hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, white or pale green flowers, followed by berries that are dispersed by birds. Diapedium ciliare relies on its host for water and nutrients but can photosynthesize to some extent. Its presence can sometimes cause stress to the host tree, though it is not typically harmful.
